posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>135338657
Show has changed a bunch. It's hard to summarise it easily, but the show itself sort of acts like a journal for the creators so you see their opinions on things grow and change over the years as they get older (and you also see them cover the current events over the years, controversies and politics etc). Certain characters and dynamics get more focus over others, for example Kyle and Cartman's rivalry becomes much more prevalent in the seasons after 7. Characters like Randy end up moving into the spotlight as Trey finds himself relating more to Randy than Stan with age, so a bunch of Randy focused episodes get made.

They experiment with serialisation with some 3 part special episodes usually with higher stakes, eventually leading to them moving to full season serialisation around seasons 19-22. They also take the Randy focus to the extreme and make big changes like making him a weed farmer for several years with his whole family moving out to a farm. Lots of people hate Randy and his Weed farm now.

Current South Park has started making longer special episodes because of a streaming deal, as well as shorter seasons. It is kind of in a new era after the serialised/weed farm era. Lots of people think the quality of the show has degraded over the years. Which is true, the thing people can't agree on is where exactly is the point it becomes unwatchable, or if even the newest episodes are enjoyable or not.

Honestly at a certain point it stopped because Zack’s fault. If they had just carried on with his continuity, maybe bit the bullet and recast actors earlier, and just generally carried on trying stuff, they’d probably right now have a half way decent canon comparable to the MCU that was maybe a phase or so behind depending on how rigid you wanted to be about it. But all this crowing about not having the perfect start, the ego over whose fault it was and how they can reboot while still honoring old contracts, just left them spinning their wheels for over 6 fucking years and now no one is left in the audience to give a shit. If you cared about the Snyder canon, you’re fucked because they’ve dumped it, if you wanted a fresh slate you’re fucked too because they’re not fully dumping it just clearing away clutter. Either way there’s nothing to latch onto, which is what Marvels secret has been for years. The MCU was never perfect, it fucked up constantly, but that unified central “continuity” they had kept people under the illusion it was going somewhere and now they won’t quit watching even when it’s become clear that the post Endgame era is directionless. WB meanwhile was always getting themselves twisted up over what Reddit thinks, fumbling to stand out yet be familiar yet be varied yet be uniform. The riddle of “how do we undo Man of Steel” was always as simple as just trying again with a different director or script in the sequel and not worrying about the first one so much. Cavil should’ve been retired from the role already but with 4 films under his belt and being regarded as the modern Reeves. But instead his legacy is one of being jerked around and wasting his best years waiting for a chance that never came. Y’know despite making questionable choices there’s a reason all the actors in those films always defended Zack Snyder, because he actually respected them, and respect is worth way more at the end of the day.

>>135349412
I was an intern at DiC Entertainment until 2001 when I discovered a VHS tape labelled Sonic Underground episode 52: Do not syndicate! Curious, I put the tape in the VCR and pressed play. There was (sure to give me an A+, FreddyFox) clapperboard text at the beginning reading “Do not syndicate: Property of Sega and DiC Entertainment.” Then came Sonic snorting what I thought was flour, but then realized was crack. Sonic said “I must fulfill my mission: to kill Manic!” I said “What?” Sonic would never do that. Sonia appeared and said “Hi, Sonic, what’s-“ Sonic said “Don’t you talk trash to me, motherf#$&*er!” I was shocked at what Sonic said. Sonic grabbed a real gun and shot Sonia in the leg. Crimson blood seeped out of her wound. Sonia said “What the f#$&, Sonic?” then died. Manic appeared. Sonic said “Hello, green jacka$$!” He shot Manic in the face and he died. Sonic said “I am part of Satan’s sins. I must kill myself to make him proud.” Sonic then committed suicide. The credits rolled, and then the VHS ended. I ripped the tape out of the VCR. I will never watch that VHS again.

Yes and no. I mean, you can look back to his birthday bash and still find sportacus chatting with Obi wan and that was what, 7-8 years ago now? So while the main cast has expanded in terms of usual suspects it's not like he exclusively used SU + Knux.
As for fleshing them out? Well that all just comes back to continuity. As it stands there are arcs that flow into each other but no real proper hard continuity - just like when he started. He's constantly retconning stuff and or reimagining stuff. There's enough for lorefags to satiate themselves but I just hope they don't restrict him too often. As it stands people are willing to join the mental gymnastics club to fill all the holes but they shouldn't feel the need.
He has established these archetypical 'truths' and 'characters' and we should just enjoy the stories based on them. Bartleby is a great example as he shifts between sociopath and damaged child depending on the episode. Even his dad was retconned.

>>135352697
I asked about this in the last thread and looked into it myself and I found that it's pretty much guaranteed not to happen. AI voice shit uses a subscription model that can get really pricy really fast.

I tried the elevenlabs.io $5/month subscription, which would let him create 10 different custom voices, but only be able to generate 30,000 characters word of dialog into text in total per month. And you can burn through that pretty quickly if it doesn't pronounce things the way you want. And for some reason really long-form dialog can gets weirdly distorted, so if you started out with an okay impression of the character, it can gradually turn into a distant-sounding bit-crushed scream-like voice. It could cost that much to make a single video.

If the site became pozzed like ChatGPT and refused to let him use some dialog, then he'd have to go back to the old voices anyway. It's just not worth it.

Otherwise, be patient, be polite, and understand the simple concept behind these words: Not posted means not available yet.

>Where can I find old Win-O'-Threads?
http://desuarchive.org/co/search/subject/Official%20Win-O'-Thread/
http://boards.fireden.net/co/search/subject/Official%20Win-O'-Thread/
(Note: This finds the OP for old threads. If you want to search for comics in the archive, clear the subject field!)

>Where can I find downloads for other comics?
Warez forums/blogs, DDL-indexing search engines (like FilesLoop), torrent trackers (like 1337x) and other P2P networks (like DC++).
If a link has been posted on 4chan, you can search for it in the Desu archive (add "http*" to searches to return only posts with links).
If all else fails, just >buy it.

>Where can I buy comics?
http://www.amazon.com/
On the various publishers' webstores, and at your local comics shop.

>Where can I find an LCS?
http://www.comicshoplocator.com/

>Where can I find out when new comics are released?
http://www.comiclist.com/index.php
http://www.previewsworld.com

>How do I download from websites that only give me .exe files?
Untick the checkbox under the download button.

>How can I find this thread every week?
If you are using the inline extension go to http://4chan.org/co/official or use the option under "Filters & Post Hiding".
If you have 4chanX go to Settings > Filter > Subject and add the following line:
/Official Win-O'-Thread/;highlight

>And last but not least
Why not?

>>135358586
I asked this myself recently, here's the reply I got:
>They are decent 90s magical capestories. You've got your Infinity Gauntlet tie-ins, eyepatch Strange, but also things like Secret Defenders and Midnight Sons tie-ins. It's not high literature, or essential reading, but if you like Strange already they're good. There's still atmosphere, narration, epic scales, nothing like the awful recent runs like Aarons with the puking and quipping and all that trash. As a completionist of my favourite characters, I got them. If you're a casual fan looking for the best stories in the medium, I can't tell you that they're worth 300$ all in all. But if you know what you're walking into, they are great and entertaining 90s magical capestories. There's no edge and pouches overload, not even Paradox is that bad, or the Lennon makeover, it's just not some groundbreaking run. I personally collect them all, but I feel the same way for most cape runs these days. I buy them because I enjoyed them as a kid, not because I think the majority of them are objectively "great" any way you cut it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>135324596
>What's your least favorite aspect of comic-making,

Networking

>why?

Would be creators only want any interaction or attention that could be loosely interpreted as being their "fan". And anything outside of that margin means you cease to exist. But when most webcomics aren't very good or interesting you're stuck schmoozing with a mob of Tommy Wiseau's. For some it's easy to lie up the self publishing caste system, but I can't stomach the game enough to use it to my advantage.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>135324596
>Thread Question: What's your least favourite aspect of comic-making, and why?
Shilling. Always felt so soulless to do so, but you must because how else do you get people to your comic? It also takes a huge amount of asskissing to pull it off. Doesn't help that most social media has been centralized and it's getting harder and harder to get noticed these days.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Also,
>What's your least favourite aspect of comic-making, and why?
Self-promoting. There has to be a balance of doing it frequently enough that people become familiar with you, but not overbearing and distasteful that makes them want to maneuver around your work. 4chan is a great way of self promoting, but… there’s still a ‘code’ to do it correctly, and dimming or removing your signatures is part of it.

What's the line between inspiration and plagiarism? Been wanting to write a webcomic around a similar concept to the Stands from Jojo's Bizarre Adventure or the Personas from Persona, but still unsure about the point when it's actually "original" or just a knock-off

posts.name: Rxxou
posts.com:
>>135340133
Take inspiration from multiple sources, combine them. Create new ideas. Take a little from everything you've ever liked and make it cohesive. What you end up with will be original and unrecognizable. If you only keep taking inspiration from one source, you'll end up with something very similar to what's already been done.

posts.com:
For a long time, I have wanted to create comics. I have come up with many ideas and plots, but after visiting a comic shop for the first time in a while, I realized that I really don't know how to start. At 20, I have wasted a lot of time not reading enough comics and not improving my understanding of the art form.

How do you write the scripts for your comics? Is it in the standard comic script format or more like a film script? Asking since I'm more accustomed to the film way of doing it. How can I improve my writing? I suppose the default answer is to write more.

Also, any suggestions for some more lesser known/indie comics for inspo? I picked up Pink Lemonade by Nick Cagnetti and Dork by Evan Dorkin to get some more "alternative" stuff.

posts.name: bermaru
posts.com:
>>135357817
>I have wasted a lot of time not reading enough comics and not improving my understanding of the art form.
don't worry about that, focus on the storytelling, it's more simple than you think.
>>135357817
>How do you write the scripts for your comics?
There's no right way to do a script , my scripts look like pic related.
>>135357817
>How can I improve my writing?
Ive been struggling with this lately, I think the best way is to make more comics. Comics is visual in a way that literature isn't. So , it's not so much about being a master wordsmith as it is conveying your ideas effectively.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>135357918
Thanks, man. I appreciate your example.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>135357918
Best thing to do when it comes to improving you’re writing is to make a few shorter stories or one offs before launching yourself into anything long form. It’ll help you get a better feel for pacing and when to introduce plot beats. Too many fledgling comic authors/artists try to start with their grand years-long magnum opus, and it rarely works out.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>135354931
It's an interesting conundrum. Most of the show's official thumbnails have the characters from around the shoulder on up, or just faces, with maybe an effect in the background. It's probably an attempt to play into Youtube interest grabbing techniques, in addition to the "be identifiable from a distance or on a small screen" that the other anon said. But when people make a thumbnail to generate interest in a matchup, that's generally not our aim. We're not using them as Youtube thumbnails, we're trying to get people interested in the story behind the matchup. In that way, we're more incentivized to use whole body profiles. Most people make backgrounds, cutting out the original background of an image to insert their own. I personally try to find images, background included, that tell the story of each character and at the same time find images that has a style that either matches or interestingly contrasts the other.

This right here. By having a premise that was inherently silly and then playing it totally straight, KND was able to have it both ways: the stories were both humorous AND worked as straightforward, serious adventures.

What happened with Kanye was my breaking point. It represents everything from our Mental Health Crisis, the repackaging of Human Suffering as a Product, our Frustration at how detached our political machinery has become from our own benefit...

A million things.

Including how we're still so culturally prone to blaming shit on The Jews when everything we're going through now is just NeoLiberal Consumer Capitalism.

But I don't know if you're aware of it, but Adidas is continuing to sell Yeezys without any earnings going to him. I don't fucking about the shoes, but there is an explicitly counter interest in "Authentic" Yeezys.

Someone is still trying to make money off him, and some of the people buying the shoes he was involved in the design of are misguided, but a retaliatory action is being taken.
I never cared for Rick & Morty, been attempting not to process what the specifics were, I'm not invested in what's happening over there and, I know this is funny, but I fucking hate conspiracy theorizing on principle (Look up Kerry Thornley / Operation Mindfuck)...

And yet I can't help but feel that Business has find a new and exciting way to make money.

So far I got 4 things
>Comedy
Obviously. Clown gags lend surprisingly well to humorous sexual situations
>Uniqueness
They stand out and there's no other character type similar to them
>Appearance
Makeup can accentuate cuteness + eye catching colors on their strange outfits can make for striking designs
>Personality
They're silly, peppy, playful and generally pleasant. Their entire purpose is to make people happy, there's nothing pretentious about about them

>>135356378
I feel like working a more physically demanding job would actually introduce the risk that he accidently reveals himself. If he's sitting in an office all day, there's never going to be an opportunity where he might get hurt or destroy something; but if he's working on a construction yard, how long would it take before some kind of accident exposes him? Or even just people start asking why he's so strong?
Plus, and this is another point, Clark chose to become a reporter as a way to respond to crime. Before he was the godlike being with super-hearing who could respond to every crime in the blink of an eye, Superman actually needed someone to tell him that crime was happening before he could show up to stop it. A more physical job wouldn't provide that.

>>135358598
>Is it still as good as I remember it being?
It's Tom King's first "superhero with PTSD" story. He's basically a one trick pony, but the first time he performed the trick got more praise and attention than when he kept doing it. As Vision was a less popular character he got a lot less pushback from fans than when he moved up to Batman.

>Did longtime Vision fans like it?
I can't speak for everyone, but I didn't, and haven't seen many that did. The idea of Vision having PTSD is such an obvious one it's surprising nobody thought of it before, but the execution of it by King only hurt him as a character, (and Victor too). The dialogue was just off, I get that King was trying to make the entire Vision family seem weird and inhuman in how they talked, but he's been around for decades, we know he doesn't talk like that.

And at a time when the MCU was obviously doing Wanda/Vision, this was the SECOND comic story in 2015 trying to keep them apart by Vision getting a new robot family. The flashback issue that was released the same month as the Civil War movie had King's story trying to make it look like Wanda and Vision were always doomed from the start, and had egregious retcons like Vision always knowing their twins weren't real (in a comic published ten years after they ended up being real and coming back).

If Cain's Vision mini had been published, I imagine it would have been even worse, though I am curious about Volton being in it, that's an obscure deep cut.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The whole premise of the movie is that due to a botched spell, people who happen to know that "Peter Parker is Spider-Man" are pulled inside this universe. It's a bit of a stretch already that amongst those people is...Peter Parker himself, twice over, but let's say it makes sense. The problem is that Electro does not meet this condition; he never found out. You could say it's a retcon or it's a different universe from the original movie's, but even this cop-out explanation is negated by the movie itself when Max Dillon makes a joke that shows that he didn't know Spidey's identity or even race.

Otto Octavius in this movie instantly recognizes the Green Goblin as Norman Osborn, a fact that was never public at least as long as Ock lived. On the other hand, he does not react to Lizard being revealed as Curt Connors, who was a colleague of his in 'his' universe but never a freaky mutated dinosaur like in the 'other' universe and neither does Peter 2. Also, Doc Ock is supposedly from Spider-Man 2 yet here he's gained a sweatshirt or turtleneck whereas in that movie he didn't have one. It's made clear he was pulled from his timeline just before his death, so he should be wearing the same thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Sandman's only wish is, as he repeats, to go back and see his daughter again. He helps Spider-man a few times, but at the same time he does not trust him entirely, so he does not act as full time ally. In the final battle though, at one point he explicitly sides with the Sinister Five, making for cool visuals in the battle but no sense; Electro and the others want to destroy the device that will send him home. He has no reasons to support them and every reason to prevent this from happening. As I said, cool visuals in the battle at the price of not making sense. At one point he's doing coordinate attacks on them with Electro and Lizard, he fights without chasing the box, and again, he's visually and in actions on the side of those whose victory will spell the end of his only wish, just because he wants those who wanna help him to do it faster? At no point in the battle it would make sense to do what he does.

Strange says he can't turn back time any more since he does not have the Time stone, so he'll resort to "a standard spell of forgetting." The statement is already quite odd since even with the stone he never showed anything close to the ability to revert time on a global scale for the WEEKS it would take to get back to that moment. But no worries; the "standard spell" is in fact more powerful than the Time stone; for it to work, it can't just make the people forget, or else people would learn back about Peter from the gigabytes of pictures and stories published, the Daily Bugle's archives, Flash's published book, T-shirts etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The whole "make everyone forget Peter is Spider-Man" spell is a massive plot hole: it is understood the spell works simply by making people forget Peter Parker. In no way is it implied it actually alters reality. Even if people forget Peter Parker, there still is a record of him being Spider-Man in TV shows, news broadcasts, papers, magazines, online videos, documents, police records, news records... There is no explanation given as to how exactly that spell eliminates those too.

Lastly the CG in this one is the worst out of all Phase 4 movies

Jon Watts is a great director but it's obvious that Disney and Sony restrict him too much. But it's easy to blame the Megacorpo rather than us. WE asked for this shit to happen.

Because companies go where the money is and that is what we decide, the reaction to Spider-Verse seems to be a factor over how this movie was written, even tho Spider-Verse was initially written by talented directors who wanted to tell a Masterful Black Story, not a Multiverse Epic.

Normal movies are becoming an Artform from the past, everything now must be connected to one Giant Cinematic Universe. Marvel, DC, Smash Bros, Sonic, Star Wars, Jurassic Park, Power Rangers, TMNT, GI-Joe, Transformers, The Matrix even shit like Hanna Barbera with Scoob has an Extended Cinematic Universe now. This is also happening to TV Shows as well, if you're not rebooting a pre-established franchise you are never making it into the Industry. Period.

We need to stop saying yes to Easy Cashgrabs like No Way Home, because this is the end result.

posts.sub: Doom Goes to Unspeakable Lengths to Undo the Fantastic Four's Mistake in 700th Issue
posts.com:
>In May, Ryan North and Iban Coello will celebrate 700 awe-inspiring issues of FANTASTIC FOUR with a giant-sized throwdown against the team’s legendary archnemesis: Doctor Doom!

>Making his first appearance in North and Coello’s run, Doom will attempt to use his unmatched expertise to fix the fatal misstep that kicked off the Fantastic Four’s new era. Still haunting the team and causing a dramatic rift between Marvel’s first family, readers are only just starting to put the pieces of the mystery together.

>After it’s fully revealed later this month in FANTASTIC FOUR #4, the team will be reunited at last just in time for Doom to rock their world once more! The iconic villain will embark on an epic journey across space and time to reverse the damage that his most bitter foes have unleashed on the Marvel Universe. Will he be able to succeed where Reed Richards failed? Or will his meddling make matters far, far worse?

>The over-sized spectacular will also see the Fantastic Four reach their new base of operations—not knowing that their greatest threat has made it there first! As their knowledge of LANGUAGE ITSELF begins to melt from their minds, the Four are in disarray as their existence hangs in the balance... and the greatest villain of all time finally seals their DOOM.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
“I feel privileged to be writing the Fantastic Four at any time, honestly, but getting to have a big milestone issue happen on my watch is certainly lucky—and it's an opportunity I didn't want to waste,” North said. “A big anniversary issue like this demands a similarly big story, something meaningful, impactful, and memorable. And given that it's a supersized issue with more room to play, everything aligned to do a story with the Fantastic Four's most meaningful, impactful, memorable, and supersized villain: Doctor Doom.”

“Doom demands nothing less than the biggest issue of the year being dedicated to him, and I dare not defy Doom,” he continued. “It's a big twisty story that brings the Fantastic Four to their new home and views what's happened to both families over the past year in a new light. The Fantastic Four are down, but not out, and Doom senses an opportunity...”

>Since the series launched last year, North and Coello have kept readers on the edge of their seats with world-class sci-fi storytelling that only the Fantastic Four can deliver. Don’t dare miss a single issue as the true depths of the Reed, Sue, Johnny, and Ben’s current predicament have only begun to unravel! Check out Alex Ross’ latest breathtaking cover below and pick up FANTASTIC FOUR #7, the colossal 700th issue, when it hits stands on May 17!

SOURCE: https://www.marvel.com/articles/comics/fantastic-four-700-issue-doctor-doom-undo-mistake

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>135352161
It's a cinematic plot device they're using, where you start at the action, then either go back and come to the event, or time skip ahead and show how it effected everything. The thing is, it's not bad in cinema, your payoff is within an hour or 2, and if it was meh, you didn't waste that much time on it. TV does similar stuff, but usually by a midseason cliffhanger they've shown the event, so you're looking at 6-8 weeks, so if the build up was for nothing it feels worse than the movie, but still not pointless. However with these, you're looking at months to a year before any payoff, and if it was worthless, it's all a waste of time because everything will revert back within a year. The worst one will be One Piece, because if it turns out the One Piece is the friends we made along the way, Luffy's Devil Fruit, or we never find out by the end, it will have been a decade long ride for nothing

And the idea here is Marvel is trying more cinematic storytelling so that they can adapt arcs for the screen easier, meaning easier MCU movies.

>How does this work?

>It works like a community toy chest. In the /coc/ threads you are free to post whatever ideas/settings/characters you want, but you have to be OK with other people playing with them (tweaking them, putting them in stories, using them for things, etc.)
>There's no guarantee that what you post will catch on either.

>If the OC you are posting is YOURS for something you are personally doing, then it would go to the "How is your webcomic?" threads.
>If you just want feedback on an OC of yours, then it would go in the "donut steel" threads or drawthreads.

If the thread dies suddenly or you still want to discuss something when there's no thread:
https://boards.plus4chan.org/coc/

He already fights creatively by making his enemies lighter or heavier when not hitting them with his hammer.
He dashes through a crowd of thugs, and with just a touch makes them all heavy as lead and on the ground without much fuss. The problem is they only stay heavy for a moment and in that moment he has to do something to incapacitate them further, but in that moment they also become super durable.
Or he could make them lighter, light enough to float off of the ground high enough so when it ears off, they're in for a painful landing.

These are all things that have been discussed and implemented in scripts.

What he can learn, it making decisions faster and how to press his advantages further.

Is it a metaphor? Or it just a swamp filled with demons trying to find a lucky magic seed burred in the putrid muck.

Well, goodnight.

Durlahan the Bulwark, and Denkala the Astromanth.

Two members of a group known as the Aspects of the Totem. The Totem is a carved boulder located deep beneath The Mountain, where upon it breaths power into the world. An aspect is chosen at birth, and will hold it until they die. Denkala and Durlahan are the oldest of the Seven aspects of the Totem, being well over two hundred years old. Along with the other four, they seek the Seventh Aspect whose power has yet to reveal itself.

The Bulwark protects the Totem, whilst the Astromanth works like its mind.

They are. Before the Seventh Aspect was born, the one before them was killed. The simple fact that someone out there was able to overpower an Aspect and outright murder them shook the Seven to their very core, creating an anxiety that weakened their souls and allowed darkness to inhabit them. If this were a video game, then the Player would have to find the Seventh Aspect whilst putting down the Six still remaining.
Durlahan would be the second to last, with Denkala the final.

>>135357598
Margalan the Druid - The Third Aspect on the Totem and Aspect of Nature. As the embodiment of nature, its health is reflected in her. During times of plenty, she is as strong and fit as any knight and strongman. During times of famine, pestilence, or harshness, she is as frail as a young girl. She can hear the cries of the forests and the beasts, and feels the pain or joy of the world. The Anxiety that has afflicted her has her withdrawn into the mountains, hidden amongst the grove and protected by Nymphs and Satyrs. The very land has grown into a twisted nightmare around her and has begun to spread to the villages around her grove, and even the animals flee at her sight.

To put her out of her misery would bring peace to all.

>>135352400
Animal companions can mean a few things. a wizard's familiar? Fine, they die easily but can be summoned for a bit of gold. You can magically see through their eyes making them excellent scouts. They don't do much in combat (unless they are an owl) but that's okay.

The beastmaster ranger however? when it first came out it was considered the worst class/subclass in the game. In order to have the beast companion make an attack, you had to give up one of your own attacks. And a lot of the time, a character's weapon attacks will just be better than the beast's attacks thanks to magic weapons and feats like sharpshooter. So you were actively weaker for using your subclass. The beast basically served as a meat shield on the battlefield, but the problem was that if it died you had to go find a whole new beast to form the bond with. Which obviously Laura didn't want to do anyway since she was attached to trinket. Also, the beast companions used actual monster stat blocks for different animals, and some were considerably more useful than others, but all were still pretty shit.

Since then they actually released a patched, updated version that fixes a lot of problems. First of all, you can instead of having it replace one or your attacks have it attack with a bonus action instead, meaning you still get your full action for yourself meaning your subclass actually makes you stronger, not weaker. They also changed it to three beast templates, a flying template, a swimming template and a land template that you can apply to a wide variety of animals so they are more balanced against each other. You can also resummon the beast like a familiar, so you don't have to go out into the forest to find a new one if you don't want. This has made beastmaster a much better and viable class, but this change was implemented after campaign 1 of critical role had finished.

Alright, let's get this started. Before anything else, I just wanted to say last week's episode was a grower. Don't get me wrong, I liked it even at the time and said as much but I really found myself thinking back to it later in the week and genuinely enjoying it even more. I mentioned in that review how if someone said they liked it even more than the music video episode I could see where they're coming from on that opinion and now I feel that way even more. Great episode.

Now on to this one. I've mentioned that ever since around episode three, the show has noticeably improved every episode and plateaud at a really nice place. I've always been worried about whether it's just on a hotstreak and some of the old issues are going to rear their heads but it doesn't really feel that way to me anymore. It's maintained the quality and the impression I get is as they've gone on they've simply figured out the nuances of the show's concept and how to structure, film it and time it. Apart from some little wrinkles here and there pretty much every episode is solid to quite good.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>135337928
This episode specifically is the funniest episode in the series so far. Gracious. Extremely dense with jokes per scene but without being cloying or annoying about it either. What I mean by that is that it's not 'hey let me briefly bring this story to a halt so I can make a joke' style comedy, instead all the gags are woven right into the narrative itself and are meaningful character-based buildups, payoffs or stuff that carries the plot along. Boy, I could gush about this all day because there were a lot of really excellent jokes. I feel like if I lose focus I'm just gonna start rattling them all off and talking about how much I liked them and that'll end up being my review. But man, c'mon. Even the acting was good. The whole "nice to know I'm your favorite person thing" from Luna, the way that was all built up and Lynn's Sr.'s exuberance and her teenage suspicion and how she moodily plays her dad out of the room. Top notch. It's only now that I really recall it that I was going to mention there was something tiny that bugged me about Luan's performance in that scene but the rest of it was so good it just wiped it from my mind and left me with a smile on my face the as we left.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>135338166
And damn, the reveal scene with everyone dressed up like each other! I don't watch the previews so for me that was a tremendous sight gag that really made me laugh, a surprise as I believe was intended. It was the kind of thing where if it was filmed in front of a live studio audience you'd have to pause to give the audience time to laugh. Me personally I actually paused the video so I could laugh. I think it's because it's not something you were truly waiting for it to happen so there was no expectation. I mean, you knew they were going to have to act like each other but probably don't regard their outfits as part of their personalities, but when you give it some real thought you realize Lana dressing like she does and being a supposed pageant queen would lead to questions and ditto Lucy being a comedian that dresses like a mortician. So it makes sense why they'd switch in hindsight but it's nuanced enough you're not on guard for it, which I think makes it hit even better. Well constructed joke.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>135338235
Boy were they having fun, especially the Lisa actress was really enjoying herself in that scene, you could tell that was not a fake smile. They all looked terrific in their switched outfits, it was a great comedic visual, and I liked how it was written too with all of them struggling to act like each other. That was actually really cleverly conceived as far as why it was all happening, the fucking 'eleven seemed excessive' joke was world class first of all and a great and natural excuse to split the cast, but really the whole episode could have just been your classic 'the boss is over for dinner' comedy of errors; having Flip very realistically fuck up putting names to faces/personalities in his letters about this family he barely knows and mixing up their idiosyncracies so now the kids have to act like each other on top of that, that was believable from a character perspective and smart from the grand perspective, really gave the whole plot a lot more to play with.

Funny, funny, funny. The whole thing reminded me of Cover Girls, one of my absolute favorite episodes. Having the sisters pretend to be each other is a total hit, it works every single time; it's enough to make me admire the restraint they have to have only really used that joke once (and now, I suppose, twice). Lisa visibly seething at having to pretend she needs a tutor. Lucy trying to make jokes. The only thing I didn't like was Lana farting since they'd already been a fart joke earlier in the episode, I'd have just had her burp. Everything else was top notch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Another thing, the girls that get home later being good sports and not fucking it up and also trying to stop their dad from fucking it up, I liked that, how even though they got tricked in there they're still good kids and don't want to blow it for Flip. How any excuse for theater gets Lynn Sr. stir crazy, that's where Luan gets it from. The basement situation devolving into Lord of the Flies once they get hungry enough, Luan jumping a panicked Luna for her chocolate bunny cracked me up, and then Lola assuming control. Everybody got something. I'm glad this is a two parter, you can tell this premise still has plenty of meat on the bone, I'm really looking forward to next week's episode.

Let's see, anything I didn't like? I suppose didn't like that Flip's actor didn't do a vocal impression of Flip. It was cool to see the food and fuel in real life. Lastly, this is neither a like or a dislike, but I'm confused why the plot is using a Princess Bride style storybook narrative framing device for its story. When I read the episode title I got the impression it was going to be like the power goes out episode from the cartoon where storytelling is used an excuse to put the characters in fantastical situations, but this is a pretty straightforward, grounded plot, so was there really a need? Do you guys think it was just so they had an easy way to recap the Lincoln/Charlie situation or what? I guess we'll see in episode two.

posts.com:
I watched the new episode today.

"The Princess and the Everlasting Emerald: A Royal Woods Fairytale - Part 1" was a pretty fun episode.

The framing story involves Lincoln reading a bedtime story to Lily. That was a bold approach. After 'Wake Up Moon' (must be a parody) and 'Who Needs to Fart?' (ew), Lincoln gets a much larger, meta storybook that starts the episode.

One day, Charlie tells Lincoln that she and her family are moving back to Tennessee tomorrow. Wanting to get her something to remember him by, he and Clyde find some sort of giant emerald ring (almost certainly a ring pop) at Flip's. Unfortunately, he's charging $57,000; he's been having financial troubles from inflation. He offers the emerald in exchange for Lincoln's help and parents (but not Clyde; he's going birdwatching).

It's Charity Week, where the Louds do stuff for the community. Lynn Sr. is planning to take Lynn to teach people baseball. Unfortunately, she's going to a soccer tournament. He asks Luan, then Luna to come with him, but they got gigs (and he made the faux pas of telling them they're #1 in front of the other sister). Lily and Lola are also unavailable. He laments about how he fought a raccoon to get a costume for nothing and that everyone was growing up, so Rita assures him. Lincoln comes in and enthusiastically asks for Lynn Sr.'s help. Then he reveals Flip's presence to them. He's biting a wax apple because he's a buffoon, as we know too well. And he's here for a wife. Or rather, Rita and the kids to pass off as his own.

Linc and Flip host a presentation introducing his more successful brother Walter. He's been borrowing money from him, but he couldn't tell him the real reason why or else he'd demolish Flip's Food 'n' Fuel. So he's been claiming that the Louds were his family. Or rather, Rita and five of the kids, because eleven? Even Flip says having that many kids is irresponsible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>135341878
Anyway, Walter is coming, and they needed to keep up the ruse or else he could lose his store. Lynn Sr.'s in, but Rita has to be assured that it'll be just for the one night. Unfortunately, he takes Leni, Lucy, Lana, and Lisa for Lisa, Luan, Lola, and Leni, respectively. And he doesn't want Lynn Sr. in either, so he tries to shove him into the basement. Lynn Sr. begs Lincoln to stop him when he comes by. In perhaps one of the top 10 anime betrayals of history, Lincoln tickles his father and he falls down the flight of stairs. The door is locked just as Walter arrives.

Flip introduces the Louds to him, with the girls being disguised. Lincoln heads to the kitchen just as the other siblings come home from their events, and he makes them go down to the basement, claiming that their Dad approved of it. Obviously false. Then he proceeds into a pretty egotistic rant. He's jealous of Flip usurping his role as the dinner begins. Soon he sneaks out. The other girls try to pull him back in, but he distracts them and escapes. He then heads to the garage to get a costume and is attacked by a raccoon. Upstairs, he claims Lucy was class clown and that Rita had extra thumbs that he had surgically removed. Lincoln tries to get Walter out only for Lynn Sr. to arrive dressed in a blond wig and lederhosen. Walter demands to know who that man is.

He passes himself off as Kristoff Bollschwarzenegger German Shepherd von Trapp (try saying that five times fast); Kristoff Boll for short. Lincoln claims he's their new handyman; he also claims to be a movie star and a brain surgeon. Linc and Flip try to get him out, but he persists in trying to stay. Downstairs, the girls start fraying at the nerves from starvation as the others eat Lynn Sr.'s lava cake, causing them to go berserk. Walter is about to leave. Unfortunately, Lynn Sr. and Flip's one-upping of flattery ends up causing Walter to decide to stay another day, much to everyone's dismay. Lola promptly channels John Rambo.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>135341902
Yeah. Walter expresses his disillusionment at his work. And he affirms his decision to stay another day, and he asks Lynn Sr. to fix the toilet.

Meanwhile, Charlie has been calling Linc. When he answers and asks what time her bus to Tennessee leaves, she says there was a change in plans. She's leaving Michigan tonight. He plans to meet up with her at the bus station. Of course, that's for next week.

This episode was pretty great. It was nice to see them doing a two-parter for this series. So the waiting game begins. As for this entry, it was pretty fun. There were plenty of great jokes and hilarious character interactions, like with Lynn Sr. and Flip. And speaking of, Flip does quite well here. The writers knew how to make him a lovable rogue. That's the kind of writing the main show ought to look up to. Combined with Kevin Chamberlin's performance, and I'd say it has elevated the character. Of course, Brian Stepanek is the show stealer, and Stephen Tobolowsky gives it his best. Nice to see him in the franchise again after so long.

The jokes poking fun at the idea of the Louds with eleven kids really sold it. It was actually pretty funny. And the other siblings were great in this episode being split up. Since this is a two-parter, pacing is very solid, and there's plenty of time to breathe even more than usual, considering that there is still more to come. But even then, everyone gets their own screentime, showcasing their balance.

If there is a complaint, it's that there's a tad too much toilet humor. It wasn't that egregious, but I think they could have toned it down a bit at the beginning. Otherwise, this was a pretty good.

On it's own, I give it a 9/10.

It bugged me a little how, when Charlie tells him that he's leaving, that instead of being really shocked or bummed Lincoln's reaction goes so quickly to wanting to give her something he'll remember her by. It's like he skips that part of the emotional process. If that's the way they were going to do it, then I think it would have been better to rewrite the swingset scene to have it open with Lincoln saying something like "I can't believe you're really leaving." and her replying "Yeah, my dad got another job back in Tennessee." etc. since that's basically how it played out. That would have made Lincoln's quick acceptance feel more organic if it was established it was something he knew about beforehand.

You know, it's little things like that that make me feel like even with all the stuff The Really Loud House has going for it, the show's still only good, not great. I still like the cartoon better, I think it's sharper about that kind of thing for one. The thing is though the usual issues in live action adaptations nowadays isn't just the odd characterization misstep but massive, blundering incompetence on almost all fronts, so from that perspective it seems almost absurd to complain. I mean when you compare what I just mentioned to the truly catastrophic problems of stuff like Cowboy Bepop or Sandman or She-Hulk, Hell, there IS no comparison. Most of the shit out there right now is a disaster, TRLH is more like the Speed Racer movie: flawed but cool. Me personally, I like it better than Wednesday because I feel they fucked up Wednesday in that.

Kids play a video game that alters reality and turns out to be the propagation tool to create a new universe. They talk to the people who made their universe who are grey kids with candy corn horns. Comic had a crazy random update schedules that would sometimes have multiple pages a day or sometimes nothing at all. And it was so popular that sometimes a single page would spawn hundreds of pieces of fanart and speculation, only for that page to mean very little in the long run.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've never seen any classic cartoons that weren't WB, Disney, or Tom and Jerry

So what are the must watch toons from the others, and do restored remasters exist?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Sup anon I can help out on this.

If you want my personal opinion I can sum up the best of the old age like this:

Paramount is a good place to start. Lot of good shit there.

Popeye: Pretty much any of them from the 30s will do. Be weary when you get to post-1939 until like 1942 or so, it gets insanely hit and miss. From like 1943 until 1947 or so the cartoons get great, then slowly peter out year by year. Jump out after 1950 unless you want massive depression.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Betty Boop: Legit any of them pre-Code are some of the greatest cartoons ever made. You will barely be disapointed. Moment Betty Boop gets unsexy, walk away. There's some good ones (I like MORE PEP and basically any that have Grampy in it), but unless you're severely coombrain and seeing Betty turns your on, don't bother.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Woody Woodpecker: This guy's awesome. Although the first few Woodys are a lot of fun, they don't become God-Tier until 1944 or so when he got redesigned. Rest of the 40s on, you will be in cartoon bliss. 50s is mixed, but you love stupid mindless cartoon violence, the cartoons will have you covered. 60s are basically shitpost cartoons: some of them are legit ahead of the curve, others are unbearable. 70s, don't even bother.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Superman: Despite the Fleischer brothers not really wanting to do them, they legit are some of the most influential cartoons ever made. You're in luck too, they're all restored too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Last two I'll recommend: FELIX THE CAT. This guy was legit the best silent animated character, and it's not hard to see why. Pretty much all of his cartoons are PD now, so just lurking Youtube should give you want you want. I recommend starting on FELIX TURNS THE TIDE, one of the most metal silent cartoons ever made.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Last up for bat: Oswald the Lucky Rabbit. There's a lot of cartoons with this guy, but for my money, the best ones and the funniest were done at Lantz from like 1930-1934. Some of them have the same mindset of Youtube Poopers, so if you like batshit insanity, look there.

>>135354262
Review
>Hamnesia
It was fun up until the plot twist. The song was nice, and I really liked the villain at the beginning even if she wasn't real
Also I feel like hamster gained his memory back too quickly..I get there's a time restriction but surely there was a better way to go about writing the ep so it didn't feel so sudden? The bonding moments felt forced too
>Romancing the Scene
This was a great episode and a big step up from the last one. We get more Nordle and Gretel interaction showing them having conflicting views on things. Then there's a plot device that is a pastry which has evil powers. Exclamation finds out about the pastry and reveals to Nordle he's a supervillain, and Nordle has to basically decide whether to become evil and lose his friend Gretel (they work together in the ep fighting a robot which brings them closer together) or to stick by his friend but lose the approval of his dad. They also reveal why Exclamation's arms are so short too. Unlike the last episode I don't really have any issues with this because it was timed well and didn't feel rushed at all. The B plot with Kevin & Hamster at the vet was also nice.
>Hamnesia - 4/10
Romancing the Scene - 6/10
My final thoughts, Hamnesia was pretty pointless and mostly filter and in general was just kinda bad and had an unesscary plot twist that the episode didn't need. Romancing the Scene was good because it developed the characters relationships more and I'm looking forward to seeing how this plays out in the future with Nurdle knowing his dad is evil but himself not wanting to be evil. I think the writers are trying to make Gretel and Nurdle closer and I don't really mind that as long as it's done subtly, which is what they've did.
